One of the most contentious issues in this year's presidential election has been international trade, and it's controversial in other countries, too.
Public hostility in Europe has stymied a huge trade agreement between the U.S.
and the EU.
And now, a free-trade deal between Canada and the EU called CETA is falling apart.
That's because Wallonia, a region in Belgium, refuses to accept it.
NPR's Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson reports from Berlin.
Canadian Trade Minister Chrystia Freeland looked like she was about to cry as she walked out on Walloon officials in the Belgian town of Namur.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
(Speaking French).
She told reporters, ""Canada worked really hard, as did I, to make this trade deal happen.

But it seems the European Union is unable to conclude an agreement."" The Walloon president, Paul Magnette, was more optimistic, telling reporters that, quote, ""difficulties remain, but talks would continue."" Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is scheduled to come to Brussels next Thursday to sign the pact, but Magnette suggested he delay his trip.

His tiny French-speaking enclave has the power to kill the deal because Belgium's constitution requires all of its regions to agree before the country can sign the trade pact effecting a half billion people.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
(Speaking French).
Magnette told the Wallonia Parliament earlier this week that the deal as it's written will hurt local farmers and decimate Europe's labor, environmental and consumer standards.
He also objects to the establishment of independent arbitration courts, which he fears will side with multinational companies over local enterprises.

But EU president Donald Tusk told reporters following a summit in Brussels that he sees another issue at play - the long-running feud between the minority French and majority Dutch-speaking regions of Belgium.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
The problem with CETA and Wallonia today, it's not a formal or technical dilemma or problem.
We witness here also the internal politics in Belgium.
Tusk says EU officials will scramble over the next few days to break the logjam and realize a deal that promises to deliver to Europe billions in added trade through tariff cuts.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
I remain concerned for a good trade agreement with our close partner and ally, Canada, and for Europe's reputation.
If CETA fails, he and other European leaders warn that the bloc's credibility will be ruined.
That, they add, could prevent the EU from closing similar trade deals with the United States and Japan.
Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson, NPR News, Berlin.
Detroit has filed for bankruptcy.
It was once one of the country's biggest cities and the wealthy hub of the auto industry.
But after decades of population loss, tax revenues have dried up and public services are in decay.
As Quinn Klinefelter reports from member station WDET, yesterday's filing poses an uncertain future for Detroit's citizens and creditors.
In his suite at City Hall, Detroit Mayor Dave Bing, wearing a look of resignation, tried to put the best face on a situation he's battled for more than four years.
Detroit, bleeding cash and nearly unable to pay its bills, is going bankrupt.
I really didn't want to go in this direction.
But now that we are here, we have to make the best of it.
This is very difficult for all of us, but if it's going to make the citizens better off, then this is a new start for us.
Bing really had no choice.
Detroit faces a budget deficit of nearly $400 million and roughly $18 billion in long-term debt.
Michigan's governor declared the city in a fiscal emergency and appointed bankruptcy attorney Kevin Orr as an emergency manager over the city's finances.
Orr says Detroit is at the point of no return.
I'd throw in those raw cranberries and the sugar.
Then, I would add a lot of fresh ginger, and I would add a whack of chili to this.
From NPR News, it's Day to Day.
I'm Alex Cohen.
Think of a Russian winter and you might imagine snow and birch trees, something reminiscent of Dr. Zhivago's white wonderland perhaps.
In real life Moscow, however, things are not quite as pretty.
It's mostly dirt and ice.
Muscovites wage daily battles to stay clean and on their feet.
NPR's Moscow correspondent Gregory Feifer ventured onto the streets and filed this report.
Shops and restaurants line this upscale boulevard near the Kremlin, just like in any other major city.
But look down and there is now mistaking you're in Moscow.
Smack in front of a busy bus stop a vast puddle of dark round slush greets people getting off buses.
Natalia Mikhailena(ph) say it's nearly impossible to navigate any of Moscow's streets without trouble.
(Through Translator) I slipped and fell just the other day and had to go straight home to change my clothes.
The city authorities don't remove the ice.
They just sprinkle some kind of dirt on top.
It's filthy and it ruins your shoes.
Turn off the main streets and the narrow sidewalks are covered with hard pack snow.
Something Engineer Sergei Yorgovitz(ph) says makes walking extremely difficult.
(Through Translator) If it's icy, I try to stay in inside.
And it's icy a lot.
The elderly like me have to judge every day whether going outside is worth it.
The city employs municipal workers, some of them elderly men and women, to chip away at the ice and snow.
Fifty-six year old Yugini Konstatinovich(ph) says he's working to the bone for a miserly wage and he even had to make his own shovel from wood.
(Through Translator) It's very hard to keep up when it's snowing.
It's not my fault the snow builds up.
I'm only mortal.
I can't be everywhere at once.
Muscovites say their city was cleaner in Soviet days.
Today, a Moscow's filth comes from polluting factories, dust from the city's many construction sites and the bare dirt of poorly landscaped public spaces.
But most of the city's air pollution comes from the thousands of cars cramming the streets.
Moscow is a city of cars.
They parked all over sidewalks and zoom through pedestrian crossings causing people to sprint for safety.
But drivers have their own complaints.
Wash your car and it will be coated with grime within minutes.
Taxi driver Mikhail Lipatov(ph) says much of it comes from chemicals dumped by snow plows
(Foreign language spoken)
He says they form a film on windscreens that's hard to wash off.
The Moscow authorities deny they are at fault.
Andrei Sibian, the official in charge of the city's streets blames car owners.
(Through Translator) Dirty streets are unavoidable in any city.
One thing we could do is enact stricter punishments for people driving dirty cars.
